author: Joanna Mather
title: 80pc of retirees will still draw pension in 2050
text:
FSC chief executive Sally Loane said: "We do not save enough inside or outside super." Sahlan Hayes by Joanna Mather Eighty per cent of retirees will still be drawing a part or full pension in 2050 – six decades after the start of compulsory superannuation, the Financial Services Council says.
The figures challenge assumptions that the super system will ease the weight of the pension on the federal budget.
"The reality is that we do not save enough inside or outside super," FSC chief executive Sally Loane said on Thursday.
"Because of this, 80 per cent of us will still be accessing either the full or part pension by 2050.
"That's a huge number – 80 percent after 60 years of compulsory super."
The FSC asked advisory firm Rice Warner to model the affect of the Coalition government's decision to pause compulsory super contributions at 9.5 per cent for seven years, rising gradually to 12 per cent by July 2025.
The modelling shows the pause at 9.5 per cent will result in a $136 billion blowout in the retirement savings gap.
Ms Loane said the only time the report showed the gap closing was when the super guarantee was at 12 per cent.
